subject: AI
title: Human-Initiated Triggers
description: Letting humans kick off AI workflows with buttons, commands, and forms.

hook.text: A manager highlights 50 emails and clicks 'Summarise All.' An AI workflow processes each email and delivers a one-page digest in 30 seconds. The trigger was human, the work was AI.

buildup.text: Not all workflows should be fully automatic. Human-initiated triggers: buttons in apps, Slack commands (/summarise), form submissions, or manual API calls. The human decides when to start.

discovery.text: Human triggers are ideal when: the workflow needs context the human provides, the output is high-stakes (human reviews first), or the task is on-demand rather than continuous.

twist.text: Human triggers + automated workflows is often the sweet spot. The human handles ambiguity and context. The AI handles volume and speed. Neither does the other's job.

climax.text: Design the trigger UX: make it obvious what will happen ('Summarise these 50 emails'), show progress, and present results clearly. The best trigger is one click that saves an hour.

punchline.text: One click to start. AI does the work. Human reviews the result. Best of both worlds.
